title: Banking
subtitle: From Intermediation to Disintermediation: The Paradigm Shift in Financial Services
introduction: The banking system is the core infrastructure of the modern economy, but its fractional reserve system and centralized architecture are also the root causes of financial crises. Bitcoin offers a peer-to-peer value transfer method without banks, challenging the necessity of banks as financial intermediaries. This is not just technological innovation, but a fundamental rethinking of the nature of financial services.

content.subtitle: Fractional Reserve Banking
points: Reserve Requirements: Banks only keep a fraction of deposits as reserves
Credit Creation: Creating new money supply through lending
Money Multiplier: Mechanism that amplifies money supply
Systemic Risk: Possibility of bank runs

content.subtitle: Role of Central Banks
points: Lender of Last Resort: Providing liquidity during crises
Monetary Policy: Controlling economy through interest rates
Financial Regulation: Maintaining financial system stability
Payment Systems: Managing national payment infrastructure

sections.title: Payment and Settlement Systems: Complex Intermediary Networks

content.subtitle: Traditional Payment Process
points: SWIFT System: International inter-bank messaging network
Correspondent Banking: Chain of intermediaries for cross-border payments
Settlement Delays: T+1 to T+3 settlement cycles
Multiple Intermediaries: Involving numerous financial institutions
High Costs: Each intermediary layer charges fees

content.subtitle: Bitcoin's Direct Payments
points: Peer-to-Peer Transfers: No intermediaries required
10-Minute Confirmation: Global unified confirmation time
24/7 Operation: Not limited by banking hours
Low Cost: Only network fees required
Borderless: No distinction between domestic and international transfers

sections.title: Financial Intermediation: Trust and Risk Management

content.subtitle: Traditional Bank Intermediation Value
points: Trust Intermediary: Establishing trust between strangers
Risk Assessment: Professional credit risk management
Maturity Transformation: Converting short-term deposits to long-term loans
Liquidity Provision: Promise of fund withdrawal anytime
Payment Convenience: Providing payment tools and services

content.subtitle: Bitcoin's Disintermediation
points: Cryptographic Trust: Mathematics replacing interpersonal trust
Protocol Enforcement: Automated rule execution
Permissionless: No institutional approval needed
Self-Custody: Users directly control assets
Transparent Verification: All transactions publicly verifiable

sections.title: Roots of Financial Crises: Systemic Risk

content.subtitle: 2008 Financial Crisis
points: Subprime Crisis: Real estate bubble burst
Excessive Leverage: Banks' high-risk operations
Moral Hazard: Too-big-to-fail problem
Chain Reaction: Lehman Brothers bankruptcy triggering system collapse
Government Bailouts: Taxpayers bearing bank losses

content.subtitle: Bitcoin's Genesis Context
points: Genesis Block: Embedded Times headline about bank bailouts
Fixed Supply: 21 million cap, preventing monetary inflation
Decentralization: No single point of failure
Transparent Ledger: Everyone can audit
Immutability: Preventing post-facto rule changes

sections.title: Banking Revolution: Old vs New Models

content.subtitle: Storage and Custody
points: Bank Deposits: Bank promises to pay, but funds are lent out
Bitcoin Self-Custody: Users directly own private key control
Insurance Differences: Deposit insurance vs self-assumed risk
Access Rights: Banks can freeze accounts vs unconfiscatable

content.subtitle: Cross-Border Payment Revolution
points: Traditional Remittance: High fees, long time, multiple steps
Bitcoin Transfer: Low cost, fast, direct
KYC/AML: Traditional strict review vs Bitcoin pseudonymity
Operating Hours: Weekday limitations vs 24/7 availability
Entry Barriers: Bank account requirements vs internet access

sections.title: Central Bank Digital Currency (CBDC): Combining Traditional and Innovation

content.subtitle: CBDC Characteristics
points: Central Bank Issuance: Maintaining monetary sovereignty
Digital Form: Improving payment efficiency
Programmability: Attached usage conditions
Privacy Trade-offs: Transaction transparency vs user privacy
Financial Inclusion: Lowering financial service barriers

content.subtitle: CBDC vs Bitcoin
points: Issuer: Central bank control vs decentralized
Supply Management: Flexible policy vs fixed supply
Privacy Protection: Limited privacy vs pseudonymous transactions
Censorship: Can be frozen vs censorship-resistant
Cross-Border Use: Restricted vs globally universal

content.subtitle: Financial Inclusion Revolution
points: Financial Inclusion: Serving the unbanked population
Lower Barriers: Only smartphone and internet needed
Cost Reduction: Removing intermediary fees
Global Access: Not limited by geography

content.subtitle: Systemic Changes
points: Trust Model: From institutional trust to algorithmic trust
Real-Time Settlement: Eliminating clearing delays
Global Standards: Unified payment protocol
Transparency: Public ledger enabling oversight

keyInsights: Banks' core value is trust intermediation, Bitcoin replaces this trust with cryptography
Fractional reserve banking is one of the root causes of modern financial crises
Disintermediation can significantly reduce financial service costs
Traditional banks and Bitcoin systems may coexist and learn from each other long-term
